subject: Concept of testing classes that implement Interfaces?
msgSnippet: Given that all classes {C} implement interface X, it would prolly be most logical to define test methods which all assert the successful functionality for an
messageBody:
Given that all classes {C} implement interface X, it would prolly be
most logical to define test methods which all assert the successful
functionality for an instance of every class in {C}. This way, we can
be sure all implementations correctly work at runtime while reusing
as much test code as possible.

For example since classes {ArrayList, SortedSet} both implement
interface Collection, the same tests can be applied to both :
test_add()
test_remove()
...etc

Here is my plan on implementing this:

I will have class AllImplTest extends TestCase which will have
protected methods for each type of test. Using the Collections as an
example:

class AllImplTest extends TestCase
{
protected boolean test_add(final Collection inCollection)
{

}
}

The test_add will essentially test the inCollection to see if can
successfully add an element.

Then, I will have separate public methods to test each know
implementation of the Collection interface eg

public test_add_ArrayList()
{
ArrayList locArrayList=new ArrayList();

boolean bSuccess=test_add(locArrayList);

assertTrue(bSuccess);
}

This works great, but the only catch is, for every different type of
implementation that is created, i'd have to add the test, no biggie
though.

What do you guys think about this?
